item.title: Code Improvement (need more feedback pls)
item.dc:creator: @strucker Strucker
item.description:
@strucker wrote:

[quote=“Dan0194, post:49, topic:544872”][quote author=Strucker link=topic=663750.msg4436891#msg4436891 date=1405372451]

Just use basic abstraction for little things like the name, hp etc.

Wouldn’t I have to rewrite it all?
[/quote]omg rewriting combat is so fcn hard, once i tried, man… It’s really hard… but i wasn’t using instanceof

It’s actually not to bad. But you can’t just get right into it you gotta go into it knowing how you are going to design it and everything and take your time.[/quote]lol i deleted my post because i thought it was useless after i posted it, and well… yea the design is a really hard part for me, let me search for me half/assed.

lol this was as much as i could write

[youtube]https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=mctREILWui8[/youtube]

and the ugly code… im not really near proud of it

[code=java]package server.euthymia.entity;

import java.util.HashMap;
import java.util.Map;

import server.Stream;
import server.euthymia.entity.player.Player;

public abstract class Entity {

public boolean updateRequired;

public int maxHealth, currentHealth;

public int absX;

public int absY;

public int heightLevel;

public int id;

public int type;

public boolean combating;

public boolean inCombat;

public abstract void dealDamage(int health);

public abstract void sM(String message);

public abstract void startAnimation(int index);

public int playerBonus[] = new int[12];
public int[] playerEquipment = new int[14];
public int[] playerLevel = new int[25];

public abstract void playerSoundEffect(Entity entity, int song);
public Stream inStream = null, outStream = null;

public abstract boolean addSkillXP(int i, int j);

}
[/code]

[code=java]import server.euthymia.entity.Entity;
import server.euthymia.entity.player.Methods;
import server.euthymia.entity.player.PlayerHandler;
import server.task.Task;

public class Attack {

/*
 * The attacker
 */
public static Entity Attacker;

/*
 * The victim
 */
public static Entity Victim;

/*
 * Starts the process of attacking a victim
 */
public static void attack(Entity Attacker, Entity Victim) {
	if(Methods.GoodDistance(Victim.absX, Victim.absY, Attacker.absX , Attacker.absY, 2) && !Attacker.combating) {
		
		/********************Attacker*******************************/
		/*
		 * Sets the combating to true, so the attacker doesn't start another attacking process
		 */
		Attacker.combating = true;
		
		/*
		 * The hit
		 */
		int hitDiff = Hitting.getHit(Attacker);
		
		/*
		 * The strength bonus
		 */
		int strBonus = (int) (Attacker.playerBonus[2] * .25);
		
		/*
		 * Debug message for the attacker
		 */
		Attacker.sM("You attacked an entity");
		
		/*
		 * the attack animation
		 */
		Attacker.startAnimation(Animation
			.GetWepAnim(Attacker.playerEquipment[3]));
		
		/*
		 * update required for the attacker next anim.
		 */
		Attacker.updateRequired = true;
		
		/*
		 * Makes the sound for the attacker according to his weapon
		 */
		Attacker.playerSoundEffect(Attacker,Sound.GetWepSound(Attacker.playerEquipment[3]));
		
		/*
		 * Adds the exp 
		 * Exp = a hit * 2 added to strength
		 */
		Attacker.addSkillXP(2 *hitDiff, 2);
		
		/********************VICTIM*******************************/
		/*
		 * Deals the damage to the victim
		 */
		Victim.dealDamage(hitDiff+strBonus);
		
		/*
		 * Starts the block animation for the victim
		 */
		Victim.startAnimation(Animation.BLOCK_ANIM);
		
		/*
		 * tells the victim that he is under attack
		 */
		Victim.sM("You are under attack");
		
		/*
		 * Plays the sound for the victim of blocking according to the shield
		 */
		Victim.playerSoundEffect(Victim, Sound.GetShieldSound((Victim.playerEquipment[5])));
	
		
		/*
		 * The attacker re-attacks the victim
		 */
		reAttack(WeaponSpeed.getWeaponSpeed(Attacker.playerEquipment[3], Attacker), Attacker, Victim);
	}
}
public static void reAttack(final int weaponSpeed, final Entity Attacker, final Entity Victim) {
	Server.getTaskScheduler().schedule(new Task(2, true) {
		private int count = weaponSpeed;

		@Override
		protected void execute() {

			if (count > 0) {
				PlayerHandler.messageToAll = count + "...";
				count--;
			} else {
				if(Attacker.combating) {
					Attacker.combating = false;
					attack(Attacker, Victim);
				}
				stop();
			}
		}
	});
}

}[/code]

there are more but i cba to look for them

Read full topic

item.title: Code Improvement (need more feedback pls)
item.dc:creator: @Dan0194 Dan0194
item.description:
@Dan0194 wrote:

[quote=“Strucker, post:1, topic:544941”][quote author=Limits link=topic=663750.msg4436416#msg4436416 date=1405198124]

Just use basic abstraction for little things like the name, hp etc.

Wouldn’t I have to rewrite it all?
[/quote]omg rewriting combat is so fcn hard, once i tried, man… It’s really hard… but i wasn’t using instanceof [/quote]

It’s actually not to bad. But you can’t just get right into it you gotta go into it knowing how you are going to design it and everything and take your time.

Read full topic

item.title: Code Improvement (need more feedback pls)
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

[quote=“Limits, post:47, topic:544872”][quote author=lare69 link=topic=663750.msg4436493#msg4436493 date=1405218878]

Just use basic abstraction for little things like the name, hp etc.

Wouldn’t I have to rewrite it all?

Okay what would be ideal is if you put your code on GitHub. That way we can look through it and try help. You wouldn’t need to rewrite it but change/move a few things around really. Unless you’ve did a oopsy lol

I’m not an open source person. And are you saying I need to combine the Player and Npc class into one?

there are tons of things that players and npcs have in common: update flags, position, slot, etc.

look at this https://github.com/lare96/asteria-2.0/blob/master/src/server/world/entity/Entity.java everything in that class is common to both npcs and players. so instead of declaring two identical fields in the player and npc class we can do it once in the entity class

and then while writing code you can do this

public void action(Entity e) { e.forceChat("Hi everyone!"); e.animation(new Animation(1)); e.move(new Position(3222, 3222)); }

and the method can take either a player or npc, because both player and npc extend the Entity class! if we didn’t have an entity class we’d have to make one method for players and the exact same one for npcs.

this is a small example, but this is so useful for things like combat. why? because you only have to write it once! and even better it supports player vs player, player vs npc, and npc vs npc since its entity based
[/quote]
Thanks lare, i do understand what you are saying however the game im making doesnt treat npcs like runescape. Npcs dont even show up on the map there arent enough similarities to require an entity class[/quote]
OHHHHH you’re making your own game? thought this was rsps, my mistake

Read full topic

item.title: Code Improvement (need more feedback pls)
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

[quote=“lare69, post:46, topic:544872”][quote author=Limits link=topic=663750.msg4436422#msg4436422 date=1405198774]

Just use basic abstraction for little things like the name, hp etc.

Wouldn’t I have to rewrite it all?

Okay what would be ideal is if you put your code on GitHub. That way we can look through it and try help. You wouldn’t need to rewrite it but change/move a few things around really. Unless you’ve did a oopsy lol

I’m not an open source person. And are you saying I need to combine the Player and Npc class into one?
[/quote]
there are tons of things that players and npcs have in common: update flags, position, slot, etc.

look at this https://github.com/lare96/asteria-2.0/blob/master/src/server/world/entity/Entity.java everything in that class is common to both npcs and players. so instead of declaring two identical fields in the player and npc class we can do it once in the entity class

and then while writing code you can do this

public void action(Entity e) { e.forceChat("Hi everyone!"); e.animation(new Animation(1)); e.move(new Position(3222, 3222)); }

and the method can take either a player or npc, because both player and npc extend the Entity class! if we didn’t have an entity class we’d have to make one method for players and the exact same one for npcs.

this is a small example, but this is so useful for things like combat. why? because you only have to write it once! and even better it supports player vs player, player vs npc, and npc vs npc since its entity based :)[/quote]
Thanks lare, i do understand what you are saying however the game im making doesnt treat npcs like runescape. Npcs dont even show up on the map there arent enough similarities to require an entity class

Read full topic

item.title: Code Improvement (need more feedback pls)
item.dc:creator: @Clawz_fury lare69
item.description:
@Clawz_fury wrote:

[quote=“Limits, post:42, topic:544872”][quote author=Ashi link=topic=663750.msg4436420#msg4436420 date=1405198433]

Just use basic abstraction for little things like the name, hp etc.

Wouldn’t I have to rewrite it all?

Okay what would be ideal is if you put your code on GitHub. That way we can look through it and try help. You wouldn’t need to rewrite it but change/move a few things around really. Unless you’ve did a oopsy lol
[/quote]
I’m not an open source person. And are you saying I need to combine the Player and Npc class into one?[/quote]
there are tons of things that players and npcs have in common: update flags, position, slot, etc.

look at this https://github.com/lare96/asteria-2.0/blob/master/src/server/world/entity/Entity.java everything in that class is common to both npcs and players. so instead of declaring two identical fields in the player and npc class we can do it once in the entity class

and then while writing code you can do this

public void action(Entity e) { e.forceChat("Hi everyone!"); e.animation(new Animation(1)); e.move(new Position(3222, 3222)); }

and the method can take either a player or npc, because both player and npc extend the Entity class! if we didn’t have an entity class we’d have to make one method for players and the exact same one for npcs.

this is a small example, but this is so useful for things like combat. why? because you only have to write it once! and even better it supports player vs player, player vs npc, and npc vs npc since its entity based

Read full topic

item.title: Code Improvement (need more feedback pls)
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

Dan0194:

No offence but it looks like you came into your game with no design and this kind of thing can happen. The beauty about object-orientation is for example you can use abstraction for an npc and player because since an npc and a player have so much similar characteristics you can just put it in one file and just extend or implement it in the player and npc file. If you don’t do this your going to end up re-writing code over and over which is just redundant.

Well yeah, it is from scratch and I was having a hell of a tough time getting the basics of a game down. I have a Player.java and an Npc.java but the problem is in my game the Player and Npc are two totally different things.

Read full topic

item.title: Code Improvement (need more feedback pls)
item.dc:creator: @Dan0194 Dan0194
item.description:
@Dan0194 wrote:

[quote=“Limits, post:36, topic:544872”][quote author=Dan0194 link=topic=663750.msg4436403#msg4436403 date=1405196888]

Nobody on this thread knows about OOP? lol

Well the way you guys make it sound is like making a new class for every single thing that is located in the one file before.

It’s defiantly not just creating classes doing that itself can be redundant it’s how you use the objects. Learn the 4 principles of object-orientation and you’ll see all of your code improving a lot.

polymorphism sounds fun

polymorphism saves you from casting all the time and makes your code shorter and neater.

Problem is that it’s a fat pain in the ass to implement when you’ve passed the skeleton of the program. Also the only casts I’ve done in my program right now are like doubles to integers and such, there has been no casting with the classes I made.

There is nothing wrong with implicit casting it’s when you start using a lot of explicit casting it can get bad. Also, are you using a P.I? If you are just give up on it you need to re-write the whole thing because of it’s terrible code from the start. Try a good source like hyperion, rune-source, Apollo(uses more plugins though wouldn’t really recommend if trying to learn more java).
[/quote]
This is my own game but yeah I know PI sucks flaccid dong[/quote]

No offence but it looks like you came into your game with no design and this kind of thing can happen. The beauty about object-orientation is for example you can use abstraction for an npc and player because since an npc and a player have so much similar characteristics you can just put it in one file and just extend or implement it in the player and npc file. If you don’t do this your going to end up re-writing code over and over which is just redundant.

Read full topic

polymorphism sounds fun

Problem is that it’s a fat pain in the ass to implement when you’ve passed the skeleton of the program. Also the only casts I’ve done in my program right now are like doubles to integers and such, there has been no casting with the classes I made.

item.description:

item.title: Code Improvement (need more feedback pls)
item.dc:creator: @Docent Limits
item.description:
@Docent wrote:

[quote=“Ashi, post:30, topic:544872”][quote author=Death Style link=topic=663750.msg4436379#msg4436379 date=1405188427]

by oop they mean assigning these functions to the object

like npc.subtractHealth instead of subtractHealth(npc)

…but it is like that…

p.attackPlayer instead of attackPlayer()

etc

it seems like a lot of the code is written within the player file so i’d move them out
[/quote]
It’s not you derp. It may be proper OOP heres an example:

[code=java]public class Test {
private Player player;

public Test(Player player) {
    this.player = player;
}

public void test() {
    player.doSomething();
}

}[/code]

Notice that he’s using an object to reference the player.

OT: Okay you have a general idea on objects sure but OOP is not about having a different classes. Languages that are not OOP can have different files to hold code.

Look at the headfirst book on OOP. It’s good for beginners.[/quote]
That example you gave is how I normally do it.

Read full topic
